Author: taicho -san
Review:
Our most recent visit was late 2017. A place where the souls of the so-called Bakumatsu patriots rest. The remains of Ryoma Sakamoto, Shintaro Nakaoka, and his servant Fujiyoshi are buried. I was deeply moved by reading Ryotaro Shiba's "Ryoma ga Yuku" and started visiting graves. It was 43 years ago, and I was still in my late teens. Ryoma was very popular back then, but I don't think there were many people who came to see it as much as it is now. When I visited for the first time, I asked the shrine office where the cemetery was, and was given a map that looked like an old map. In front of Ryoma's grave, sake, 1,000 paper cranes, votive pictures, etc. were offered, and I remember that many business cards were placed. The number of sake offerings was not insignificant. I think that the people at the shrine must have had a hard time cleaning up. The atmosphere hasn't changed much in the past and now, but since many years ago, an admission fee has been required. There were pros and cons for Ryoma fans, but I understand that it was a disappointing but inevitable measure to maintain this Shoujoba. When I started visiting graves, the people around me didn't understand me, and they thought I was quite an oddball. There was no such word as grave mylar as it is today. This was my starting point, and since then I have visited historic sites related to the Meiji Restoration throughout Japan. By the way, in Yokosuka, where I live, there is a grave of Ryoma's wife Oryo (Shigaraki Temple), and I also visit the grave there. When there are movies and dramas featuring Ryoma, not just Taiga dramas, it becomes a boom, and after a few years it calms down. I was able to repeat that, but I feel that Masaharu Fukuyama's Ryoma has created an extraordinary boom. I have an actor who is a friend of mine, whose name I will withhold, and I also appeared in "Ryomaden", but when the appearance was decided, I was asked about the relationships surrounding Ryoma and the background of the times, and even here together. I even visited the grave.
Well, this is Gokoku Shrine. The enshrined deity is the country's heroic spirit. It is a place to commemorate and honor not only the patriots of the Meiji Restoration, but also those who died in the previous war, those who died in the Sino-Japanese War, and those who died for the country. Let's visit first and then climb. The basics are for you.
On the premises, there is also a monument honoring Dr. Bal, an Indian judge who was the only one who claimed Japan was innocent at the Tokyo Trials after the war. You can also see the city from the observatory.
I think that if you learn a little bit about this shrine, your impression will change greatly.
We recommend that you visit the temple at least once.

Author: 83 Koichi
Review: From Higashioji, pass through the torii and go up the slope, and at the end you will find Ryozen Gokoku Shrine. It is famous for having the graves of Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka. Originally, the patriots who died at the end of the Tokugawa shogunate were buried at Reimei Shrine. In the early Meiji era, the first Shokonsha shrine in Japan was built in this area by order of the emperor, and it continues to this day. Many spirits are enshrined here, from the patriots of the end of the Edo period to the special attack warriors of the Pacific War.

However, it is an exciting place for history lovers, but it is more of a grave than a sightseeing. The road to Ryoma's grave is like a light mountain climb, and the sidewalk is not paved, so it might be better to avoid bad weather. There were places where the road was submerged and there were places where I felt dangerous. If the weather is nice, you can see the city of Kyoto from the top of the mountain.

Author: Ms. Myself
Review: No credit card accepted. No parking. It's on top of a mountain. It is a steep slope. It is a shrine and cemetery dedicated to the heroes of the Meiji Restoration. Author: Green Kim
Review:
A place where the graves of the so-called Restoration leaders who were sacrificed during the Meiji Restoration are located. Among the numerous tombstones. The famous "Sakamoto Ryoma" is sleeping with his friend and comrade "Nakaoka Shintaro". You can also see the tombstones of "Kido Takayoshi", one of the Three Restoration, and "Takasuki Shinsaku", the Choshu cavalry commander.

We must not forget that Japan was modernized as a result of the Meiji Restoration, and with that power, invaded neighboring countries with the sophistry of Jeonghanron and harassed them as colonies for decades.

Author: „Éï„Ç∏„Ç≠„É£„Éì„É≥
Review:
A shrine dedicated to the war dead who were born in Kyoto.
It is one of the gokoku shrines in Japan, and people from Kyoto were dispatched to the harsh battlefields of Burma and Okinawa during World War II.
In Burma, many soldiers died of malaria and starvation due to an unreasonable strategy that did not consider replenishment.
A certain division was forced to withdraw without the permission of the upper management, who did not respond to repeated requests for supplies. About 60,000 people were forced to cross the Chindwin River and returned, of which 2,000 were seriously ill requiring hospitalization, and about 400 died afterward. Died.
In the dense forests of Burma (now Myanmar), the remains are still exposed.

In the Battle of Okinawa, the Imperial General Headquarters transferred the 9th Division, the most elite division, to Taiwan. In defense, it became the main force in the first half of the Okinawa line.
The 62nd Division was a veteran, and despite the difference in military strength between us, it was able to stop the enemy several times more than us and gradually retreated the front line.
In Kakazu, one of the fierce battlefields in the first half, a monument of Kyoto was erected, and traces of the battle can be seen, such as the pillbox still remaining today.

Many people also visit the grave of Ryoma Sakamoto. The adjoining museum has many exhibits such as swords from the end of the Edo period.

I pray that the spirits of the war dead from Kyoto may rest in peace.

Author: Syouzou Irie
Review:
Famous for the graves of Ryoma Sakamoto, Shintaro Nakaoka, Kogoro Katsura and Ikumatsu
There is a memorial monument for each unit of the Pacific War in the precincts, and a grave on the mountain side.
A Type 92 machine gun that returned from Burma to the cenotaph? and there is an iron helmet
There is an entrance fee of 300 yen for the graveyard on the mountain side, and there are places where the sidewalk is rough with a slope, so I think it's better to wear shoes that are easy to walk in.
Most of the visitors seem to be aiming for the graves of patriots at the end of the Edo period. Maps are posted, but for those who are not posted, the graves of Meiji police officers (Southern Rebellion?), former soldiers, the memorial monument for the destroyer Naganami, and Kyoto Prefecture. There is a memorial monument for the martyrs of the Self-Defense Forces

Author: Taiyo
Review:
I traveled to Kyoto to pay my respect to #RyomaSakamoto and to gather family registries.

Thanks to a wonderful student of mine named Noriko. I shockingly learned one of my ancestors, a doctor named Shosai Fujita, performed surgery on Ryoma Sakamoto saving his life, after Sakamoto was attacked at the Teradaya Inn.

Noriko pointed out pages 44-46 stated this. Also, other members of my family are mentioned on pages 118-120. My family registries and family testimonies on two different branches of the Fujita family, also support this narrative.

I feel proud. I also feel a bit of my inside soul is repaired also. To know where I came from is to empower oneself to continue a family legacy, to know where to walk in the future and what footprints to leave behind.

Ryoma Sakamoto was one of the founding fathers of the Meiji Revolution (Restoration in Western Historiography) and he employed diplomacy and peace to unite tribes for the dream of a modern Japan.

His grave today does not reflect the greatness of this amazing, courageous, and prudent hero of Japanese history. But may his legacy, may we who agree with a modern Japan and peace, give him a bow.üáØüáµüóæ

Author: ‰ºäÈÇ™ÈÇ£Â≤ê„ÅÆ‰∏â„ÉÉÂ∏Ø
Review:
A shrine located on a hill in Higashiyama, Kyoto, which has a deep connection with the Meiji Restoration.
The scenery from the precincts is very wonderful.

Founded in 1868 (Meiji 1). Emperor Meiji issued an edict to ``enshrine the spirits of the patriots who fell before the Meiji Restoration. It is said that the foundation of the shrine began with the construction of a shrine for patriots.

It is said to be the forerunner of Shokonsha, a shrine dedicated to the spirits of those who martyred themselves for the nation around the time of the Meiji Restoration, and was built one year earlier than Yasukuni Shrine.

There are shrines of famous figures of the Meiji Restoration, such as Takayoshi Kido (Kogoro Katsura) and Shinsaku Takasugi, as well as bronze statues of Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka. If you are interested in the end of the Edo period and the Meiji Restoration, this is a spot you should definitely visit.

Author: Massa S.
Review: Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku Shrine / Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku Shrine Near Ryozen Historical Museum. On June 29th, 1868 (May 10th, 4th year of Keio), Emperor Meiji enshrined the spirits of the patriots (Tenchu-gumi, etc.) who fell before the Meiji Restoration. An imperial edict was issued to establish a The court nobles of Kyoto and various clans such as Yamaguchi, Kochi, Fukui, Tottori, and Kumamoto, who were deeply moved by this, worked together to build shrines on the top of Mt. There is a cemetery of Ryoma Sakamoto, Takayoshi Kido, Shintaro Nakaoka, Shinsaku Takasugi, etc.

Author: Saitaniya Ryoma
Review:
It is a place where the souls of those who were born in times when it was difficult to have dreams and goals in life, but who burned their lives to protect Japan, where they were born and raised, and to protect their families, friends, and loved ones who are most important to them, rest here.
Kyoto is now a world-famous tourist destination, and has become a place where the smiles and laughter of tourists who visit here never ceases. I don't think we should forget that it was a fierce battlefield where blood flowed.
Some people say that the reason why the cherry blossoms in Kyoto bloom beautifully and are more beautiful than anywhere else in Japan is that the blood of the people who lived in that fierce era flowed in the land of Kyoto, and the cherry blossoms nourished it.
For people who are interested in Japanese history, who want to learn about it, and who want to know the value of their own existence, I think this is a must-visit place when visiting Kyoto.
There is no doubt that it is thanks to the people who sleep here that Japan is at peace today.
It is located on a steep slope and has stairs, so I think it is difficult for people with disabilities to visit, but it is also a place that makes you think about the way people's hearts and the meaning of life are.
The view of modern Kyoto from this place, which has reached the end of a steep slope, also has the atmosphere of Kyoto in the Reiwa era.
I think it is a place where you can superimpose the capital of the past and the capital of Reiwa, and at the same time, you can reflect on your life.

Satsuma-Choshu Alliance, Restoration of Imperial Rule, Eight Plans in Ships,
I think that he was the one who seriously thought about the future of Japan from the bottom of his heart.

It's already difficult to go to Kyoto,

Author: ÂéüÁî∞ËâØ‰ªã
Review: Emperor Meiji ordered the establishment of this shrine to enshrine the spirits of patriots who dedicated their lives to the country, and it was decided to enshrine the war dead since the Fushimi-Toba War. The clans of Kyoto, Yamaguchi, Kochi, Fukuoka, Kumamoto, Tottori, and Kurume, who were deeply moved by the blessings of God, each built a shrine character on Mt. It was a national Shokonsha, and the name of the company was called Ryozen Kansai Shokonsha. It was renamed to its current name on April 1, 1939. There are 549 deities enshrined in the shrine, including the leaders of Tenchu-gumi, Tadamitsu Nakayama, Ryoma Sakamoto, Shintaro Nakaoka, and Torataro Yoshimura. June 5, 1864 Yamazaki steam of the Shinsengumi informs the Kyoto Shugoshoku of a secret meeting of the patriots at Ikedaya, and is attacked by Shinsengumi Isami Kondo, Heisuke Todo, Shinpachi Nagakura, and Soji Okita. was killed and 12 people were arrested. Martyrs have gravestones in the sacred precincts of this sacred mountain. There is a detailed exhibition at the Ryozen Museum next door. From the torii of the shrine, it is named Ishin no Michi.

Author: non kun
Review:
Enshrined deity:
There are 549 deities enshrined at the Ryozen Kansai Shokonsha Shrine. The achievements of Matabei, Genzui Kusaka, Chuzaburo Terashima, Kyuichi Irie, Ryoma Sakamoto, Shintaro Nakaoka, Torataro Yoshimura, Kuniomi Hirano, Teizo Miyabe, and Izuminokami Maki are well known.
The number of imperial deities enshrined is 13,56, including those of Tofuku-ji Temple, Daiun-in Temple, and Sennyu-ji Temple's Shokon-sha Shrine, and those enshrined until Meiji 41. Since then, it has enshrined the spirits of the heroes who died in the Qing, Japanese, Russian, Manchurian, Chinese, and Greater East Asian campaigns. (As of October 13, 2001, the number of enshrined deities is 73,011.)
Enshrined place: 1 Seikanji Ryozen-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture
It was a rare gokoku shrine with a sacred mountain (cemetery). You don't need to pay to visit the shrine, but you need to pay an entrance fee to enter the sacred mountain (cemetery). Adults are 300 yen per person. However, if you come this far, you will want to enter the mountain. There are graves of Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka. There are steep slopes and stairs, so high heels are unreasonable lol
Ryoma and Shintaro were standing next to each other. From the grave of Ryoma and others, we could see Kyoto city.
In recent years, there have been various theories about the Meiji Restoration, but what is the truth? is not it.
In any case, I came back with my thanks for being born in modern Japan as a Japanese, and my thanks to the spirits of the spirits for allowing me to continue to live.
When I left the shrine and walked down the slope, the sunset was so beautiful that I took a picture of it too.
There is no parking lot at the shrine, so it is best to park in the paid parking lot of the temple in front of the shrine.

Author: YUMI KNSG

Students and tourists were walking up to the torii gate, but when I bowed to the torii gate and stepped forward, I was the only one walking‚Ä¶
The atmosphere was very strict.
I wonder if there are few people who go as a tourist spot.
I put my hands together with the patriots of the Meiji Restoration and the spirits of the previous war, put my hands together with the monument of those who died in the line of duty of the Self-Defense Forces, received a red seal, bowed once at the torii, and left.
It was so quiet that I couldn't believe it was a tourist spot.

Author: KAZUTOYO HATTORI
Review:
A shrine that enshrines patriots of the Meiji Restoration at the end of the Edo period, war dead in World War II, self-defense officers, and police officers who died in the line of duty.
I visited the graves of Ryoma Sakamoto, Shintaro Nakaoka, Takayoshi Kido, one of the three greats of the Meiji Restoration, and Shinsaku Takasugi of Kiheitai.
While making me think again that the Meiji Restoration would not have happened without these people
I put my hands together.
I would like to hear how these patriots see Japan today under their graves.

Author: Japan DNA
Review: A shrine with history and prestige that was founded one year earlier than Yasukuni Shrine under the imperial edict of Emperor Meiji. Starting with Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka, since the arrival of the Black Ships in 1863, the spirits of loyal retainers and protectors of the country, who have been busy with national affairs, are enshrined here. Showa-no-Mori and the monument honoring Judge Pearl are also must-sees.

At the end of a short staircase, there are the graves of patriots, and as you slowly turn around one by one, you can see the names of the people who appeared at the end of the Tokugawa period. I was.
I remember being moved by what happened after the assassination of Mr. Ryoma Sakamoto and Mr. Shintaro Nakaoka.

Author: D. Zawa
Review: A shrine that enshrines people who were active from the end of the Tokugawa shogunate to the Meiji period (many of whom are on the side of the Meiji Restoration, but some of them are on the side of the Shogunate). It is especially known as the graveyard of Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka, but in reality a considerable number of them are enshrined. Takayoshi Kido and his wife Matsuko are enshrined at the highest place, and this may not be well known. The view from the hill is a must-see, and you can overlook the city of Kyoto.

Author: yo ‚ÄúTS2121‚Äù sakuro
Review:
Visited on April 23, 2023.

It is a slightly dilapidated shrine. There are a lot of tourists up to the "Nene no Michi" in front, but there are few people walking the "Ishin no Michi" along the way (although it is quite steep).

Visiting the main shrine is free, but for 300 yen you can go to the area where the graves of patriots who died during the Meiji Restoration, including Ryoma Sakamoto and Shintaro Nakaoka. There is a resting place with a nice view on the way, and you can see the whole city including Yasaka Pagoda. Don't miss the grave of Dr. Pearl.

The Meiji Restoration and Joi, in the end, are killing each other, but the action that tried to realize the aspirations even at the risk of life is suitable for the name of a patriot.

The goshuin was written on the book for 500 yen. It would be a good idea to go along with the Ryozen Memorial Museum across the street.
